Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Methods for the Direct Quantification of Air Pollutant Emissions and Education of the Next Generation of Engineers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Marr 0547107 Intellectual merit. The intellectual merits of this project are that it will provide a new tool for the quantification of air pollutant emissions, that it represents the first direct measurement of anthropogenic fluxes of nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds, and fine particulate matter to the atmosphere, and that it will significantly enhance understanding of air pollutant emissions. This method is a significant advance over the current approach, which relies on engineering estimates to predict emissions. These measurements will provide significantly improved data for the advancement of air quality science and management.
Broader impacts. Ultimately, this research will lead to more effective air quality control strategies and cleaner air through both science and education. New air quality regulations are expected to cost over $6.5 billion per year and potentially save $120 billion in health-related expenses. Accurate measurements of emissions will ensure that efforts to reduce air pollution are optimized for cost effectiveness. The projects integrated educational components will have at least two significant impacts. First, introducing K-12 students to our field measurements will excite them about science and engineering and will encourage more of them to enter technical fields of study. Second, through the combination of new wireless classroom technology and active learning techniques, undergraduate students will gain a deeper understanding of environmental engineering and will be more likely to retain the knowledge throughout their careers. This technology may especially aid minority and female students to overcome cultural, gender, and social barriers that inhibit them from participating more actively in traditionally taught classes. A larger pool of better educated scientists and engineers will improve our ability to successfully tackle air pollution and other environmental challenges in the coming decades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outdoor air pollution causes 200,000 deaths per year worldwide; and in the absence of new approaches to the problem, it will be responsible for a total of 8 million premature deaths between the years 2000 and 2020. Although the link between air pollution and health effects is firmly established, air quality science and management remain hamstrung by unreliable estimates of the emissions that cause air pollution. Therefore, the chief goal of this research was to provide the first direct measurements of anthropogenic emissions at the neighborhood scale. We applied an innovative method known as eddy covariance, that has been widely used in the biogeosciences, to estimate carbon dioxide, particle, and nitrogen oxide emissions in urban areas. Carbon dioxide is the chief greenhouse gas, particles are linked to cardiovascular disease and respiratory irritation, and nitrogen oxides contribute to ozone and particle formation.

Through a series of field campaigns in a rural Appalachian town, a large city, a regional airport, and along the US-Mexico border, we measured fluxes of these pollutants, including the first-ever measurements of nitrogen oxide fluxes in urban areas. Our results confirmed existing estimates of emissions in some cases but suggested that estimates may be lower than actual emissions in others. Spatial variability in pollutant concentrations and emissions was found to be much greater than previously realized. Results from this research will contribute to the public welfare by informing regulatory policy. For example, this research answers questions about differences in air quality and emissions on opposite sides of the US-Mexico border and the importance of pollutant transport across the border. It also provides the scientific basis for questions about the impact of a regional airport on local air quality.

We applied a similar engineering-oriented approach to track the emissions, transformations, and fate of the influenza virus in air and showed that the spread of the flu via aerosols produced by coughing and sneezing is indeed feasible. We showed that humidity can influence concentrations of airborne influenza viruses by (1) controlling the extent of evaporation of droplets containing the virus and thus their removal efficiency by gravitational settling and (2) influencing the rate of virus inactivation. We also showed that the virus survives best in droplets of human mucus at low (<50%) relative humidity and at extremely high (>98%) relative humidity and is largely inactivated at in-between relative humidity. This result may help explain the seasonality of influenza and could be used to help guide infection control strategies.

The educational component of this project introduced a student response system (clickers) into three classes at Virginia Tech. Students felt that the clickers helped improve their level of understanding of and engagement with the material. The large database of multiple-choice questions that was created as part of this project is now available online.

The project has resulted in eight papers in the peer-reviewed scientific literature; eight conference presentations; new research infrastructure in the form of a mobile eddy covariance laboratory; education of the public through stories in The Wall Street Journal, Scientific American, and other media outlets; and training of four Ph.D. students, one M.S. student, and three undergraduates in cutting-edge approaches for tackling problems in air quality engineering.
